urn:contentItem:6BTX-KW61-JBSP-1519-00000-00Data on Drones Discussed by a Researcher at Nanjing Forestry University (Superpixel-Based Graph Convolutional Network for UAV Forest Fire Image Segmentation)2024-04-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:16:45ZLexisNexisAEROSPACE RESEARCH - DRONESData on Drones Discussed by a Researcher at Nanjing Forestry University (Superpixel-Based Graph Convolutional Network for UAV Forest Fire Image Segmentation)


2024 APR 18 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Defense & Aerospace Daily -- Data detailed on drones have been presented. According to news reporting originating from Nanjing, People's Republic of China, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, "Given the escalating frequency and severity of global forest fires, it is imperative to develop advanced detection and segmentation technologies to mitigate their impact."


Funders for this research include Jiangsu Province Graduate Research Innovation Program.
Our news journalists obtained a quote from the research from Nanjing Forestry University: "To address the challenges of these technologies, the development of deep learning-based forest fire surveillance has significantly accelerated. Nevertheless, the integration of graph convolutional networks (GCNs) in forest fire detection remains relatively underexplored. In this context, we introduce a novel superpixel-based graph convolutional network (SCGCN) for forest fire image segmentation. Our proposed method utilizes superpixels to transform images into a graph structure, thereby reinterpreting the image segmentation challenge as a node classification task. Additionally, we transition the spatial graph convolution operation to a GraphSAGE graph convolution mechanism, mitigating the class imbalance issue and enhancing the network's versatility."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "We incorporate an innovative loss function to contend with the inconsistencies in pixel dimensions within superpixel clusters. The efficacy of our technique is validated on two different forest fire datasets, demonstrating superior performance compared to four alternative segmentation methodologies."
For more information on this research see: Superpixel-Based Graph Convolutional Network for UAV Forest Fire Image Segmentation. Drones, 2024,8(4). (Drones - http://www.mdpi.com/journal/drones). The publisher for Drones is MDPI AG.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.3390/drones8040142.
Our news editors report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Yunjie Mu, College of Information Science and Technology, Nanjing Forestry University, Nanjing 210037, People's Republic of China. Additional authors for this research include Liyuan Ou, Wenjing Chen, Tao Liu, Demin Gao.
ORCID is an identifier for authors and includes bibliographic information. The following is ORCID information for the author of this research: Demin Gao (orcid.org/0000-0002-6704-8979).
Keywords for this news article include: Nanjing Forestry University, Nanjing, People's Republic of China, Asia, Aerospace Research, Drones, Technology.

urn:contentItem:6FJF-HKV3-RTJ9-B3JJ-00000-00Millions Face 'Critical' Fire Risk This Weekend as Heat Records Broken2025-04-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:16:45ZLexisNexisMillions Face 'Critical' Fire Risk This Weekend as Heat Records BrokenMartha McHardy

A wave of scorching temperatures and dangerously dry conditions is fueling a "critical" fire risk across the Southwest.

A dangerous combination of record-breaking heat and dry, gusty winds is putting millions of Americans under a red flag warning this weekend, as meteorologists warn of ideal conditions for fast-moving wildfires across several states.

Why It Matters

A red flag warning means critical fire weather conditions are either occurring or will occur shortly. A combination of strong winds, low relative humidity and warm temperatures can contribute to extreme fire behavior, according to the National Weather Service (NWS).

What To Know

A wave of scorching temperatures and dangerously dry conditions is fueling a "critical" fire risk across the Southwest this weekend, with red flag warnings in effect for wide swaths of Arizona and New Mexico.

The NWS has issued multiple alerts warning of gusty winds—up to 40 mph in some areas—combined with single-digit humidity levels and parched vegetation that could ignite and spread wildfires rapidly.

The warnings span key fire weather zones, including the Tucson metro area, the White Mountains and large portions of the Apache-Sitgreaves and Coronado National Forests, where conditions are expected to be at their most volatile from 11 a.m. to 8 p.m. on Saturday and Sunday.

Areas such as Pima, Cochise and Navajo Counties are at particular risk, as are the foothills of the Tonto National Forest and the Gila Wilderness.

Conditions are similarly severe across northeastern Arizona and the Little Colorado River Valley, where wind gusts could top 40 mph and relative humidity may dip to as low as 3 percent. In southern New Mexico, the Gila region and surrounding lowlands are also facing critical fire weather, with a red flag warning on Saturday followed by a fire weather watch on Sunday.

Meteorologists emphasize that under such conditions, even a small spark can quickly become uncontrollable.

The NWS reported record-breaking high temperatures in parts of Arizona and California on Friday. In Yuma and El Centro, temperatures soared 15 to 20 degrees above normal. Highs on Saturday are expected to reach the upper 90s to about 100 degrees Fahrenheit. Northern Arizona also saw record high temperatures on Friday of up to 93 degrees. Meanwhile, NWS Tucson reported that as of 1:09 p.m. on Saturday, Tucson had reached 100 degrees, marking the earliest recorded first 100-degree day of the year. It broke the previous record of April 19, 1989. The average first 100-degree day typically occurs on May 18.

Officials are urging residents and land users to avoid any outdoor burning or activity that could spark a fire. With heat records being shattered across the region, fire crews are on high alert.

"Any fires that develop will likely spread rapidly," the NWS warned, advising all agencies and field crews to prepare for fast-changing conditions.

What People Are Saying

NWS Phoenix said on X, formerly Twitter: "Record-breaking highs were recorded in Yuma and El Centro this afternoon as temperatures climbed to around 15-20 degrees above normal. High temperatures Saturday are expected to top out in the upper 90s to around 100."

NWS Tucson said on X: "As of 1:09pm today, Tucson has reached 100°. #azwx *This is the earliest first 100° day of the year on record, dating back to 1895. *The previous earliest first 100° day was April 19, 1989. *The average first 100° is May 18."

NWS Flagstaff said on X: "Windy and dry weather is forecast this weekend. Elevated fire weather conditions are expected area wide, with a Red Flag Warning issued for portions of east central Arizona both Saturday and Sunday."

What Happens Next

A red flag warning is in effect for portions of southwestern New Mexico from noon to 9 p.m. Mountain time on Saturday, with a fire weather watch continuing on Sunday.

Additionally, a red flag warning is in effect for several areas in Arizona and New Mexico. For Fire Weather Zones 150-154, the red flag warning is scheduled to be in effect from 11 a.m. to 8 p.m. MT on Saturday and Sunday. The Little Colorado River Valley (Navajo and Apache Counties) and the White Mountains are under a red flag warning from 11 a.m. to 8 p.m. MT on Sunday.

Southern Gila County and the higher elevations of northeastern Pinal and eastern Maricopa counties are also scheduled to be under a red flag warning from 11 a.m. to 8 p.m. MT on Saturday and continuing on Sunday.

Link to Image

wildfire

Jon G. Fuller/AP

urn:contentItem:6F55-WC43-RRMR-X4KV-00000-00Data from Institut Teknologi Sumatera Broaden Understanding of Environment [The performance of the weather research & forecasting model (WRF) using ensemble method to predict weather parameters]2025-02-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:16:45ZLexisNexisENVIRONMENTData from Institut Teknologi Sumatera Broaden Understanding of Environment [The performance of the weather research & forecasting model (WRF) using ensemble method to predict weather parameters]


2025 FEB 18 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Ecology Daily News -- Data detailed on environment have been presented. According to news originating from the Institut Teknologi Sumatera by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, "The performance of the WRF model is evaluated using different physical options for the Riau Province."


The news editors obtained a quote from the research from Institut Teknologi Sumatera: "There are 12 members, and the ensemble mean method is used to evaluate the temperature, humidity, wind direction, and wind speed. The primary purpose of this study is to determine the appropriate parameterization for the study area. In this study, two nested domains have been used for performance analysis, with the resolution of the coarser domain set at 9 km and the inner domain set at 3 km. The model was run for five days in 2019 during a forest fire episode in Riau Province. The analysis was carried out by looking at the values of the correlation coefficient, root mean square error (RMSE), and bias. From the weather forecast, WRF, with the sixth parameterization member, produces a better value than the others."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "RRTM and Dudhia parameterization gave better results for temperature parameters. Meanwhile, the parameterization of Yonsei University (YSU) produces better results for the parameters of wind direction and wind speed."
For more information on this research see: The performance of the weather research & forecasting model (WRF) using ensemble method to predict weather parameters. E3S Web of Conferences, 2025,604():04002. (E3S Web of Conferences - http://www.e3s-conferences.org/). The publisher for E3S Web of Conferences is EDP Sciences.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.1051/e3sconf/202560404002.
Our news journalists report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Pratama Alvin, Department of Atmospheric and Planetary Science, Institut Teknologi Sumatera. Additional authors for this research include Oktaviana Ade A., Kombara Prawira Y., Isnaenda Ikhsan Muhammad.

urn:contentItem:6DDP-N5R1-JBSP-128J-00000-00Studies from Civil Aviation Flight University of China Have Provided New Data on Applied Mathematics and Nonlinear Sciences (Research on automatic UAV path planning technology for complex terrain under neural network perspective)2024-11-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:16:45ZLexisNexisMATHEMATICS - APPLIED MATHEMATICS AND NONLINEAR SCIENCESStudies from Civil Aviation Flight University of China Have Provided New Data on Applied Mathematics and Nonlinear Sciences (Research on automatic UAV path planning technology for complex terrain under neural network perspective)


2024 NOV 14 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Network Daily News -- A new study on applied mathematics and nonlinear sciences is now available. According to news originating from Sichuan, People's Republic of China, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, "UAV path planning originates from robot motion planning, which is the core content of the current UAV application research and plays a key role in improving the operational capability of UAS in low-altitude complex environments."


The news editors obtained a quote from the research from Civil Aviation Flight University of China: "In this paper, the neural network algorithm is utilized to study the path planning problem of UAVs in complex terrain environments. A three-dimensional map model of complex terrain is created using an interpolation composition method, and an adaptation function is introduced to address the smoothness issue in path planning. The UAV's kinematic model is created by simplifying it into a three-degree-of-freedom mass and using both proportional feedback and feedforward to determine control inputs. The neural network structure adjusts the initial point, and the neural network of an obstacle penalty function and the energy function of the entire path is constructed. With comprehensive waypoint position analysis and the help of adaptive learning factors, this paper completes the path planning for UAVs in complex terrain conditions."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "This paper's algorithm for forest fire patrol can reach 100% coverage rate when applying the path planning algorithm to forest fire aviation emergency rescue scenarios. In the forest fire emergency relief material distribution, the path planned by this paper's algorithm can effectively distribute the relief materials to five target points while successfully avoiding all the obstacles."
For more information on this research see: Research on automatic UAV path planning technology for complex terrain under neural network perspective. Applied Mathematics and Nonlinear Sciences, 2024,9(1). The publisher for Applied Mathematics and Nonlinear Sciences is Walter de Gruyter GmbH.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.2478/amns-2024-3279.
Our news journalists report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Qinghai Zuo, Civil Aviation Flight University of China, Guanghan, Sichuan, People's Republic of China. Additional authors for this research include Weijun Pan, Chen Zeng.
Keywords for this news article include: Civil Aviation Flight University of China, Sichuan, People's Republic of China, Asia, Algorithms, Applied Mathematics and Nonlinear Sciences, Mathematics, Networks, Neural Networks, Technology.

urn:contentItem:6FJT-X443-RRKF-63X5-00000-00Blue Origin to Launch All-Female Crew; AI That Fights Fires?; "It changed my life": Four-Year-Old`s Heartwarming Gesture Turns Author Into Bestseller. Aired 4-4:10a ET2025-04-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:16:45ZLexisNexisCNN 104:00 AM ESTNEWSInternational041401cb.h06Blue Origin to Launch All-Female Crew; AI That Fights Fires?; "It changed my life": Four-Year-Old`s Heartwarming Gesture Turns Author Into Bestseller. Aired 4-4:10a ETCoy Wire, Isabel Rosales, Derek Van Dam

An all-female crew will embark on a space mission aboard Blue Origin`s New Shepard vehicle first the first time in over 60 years. The star-studded crew includes singer Katy Perry, and journalist Gayle King, will travel just past the point widely recognized as where outer space begins to experience a few minutes of microgravity before returning to Earth. What if AI could forecast where wildfires may erupt around the globe? A European climate research institute is just trying to do that. Scientists in Europe are using machine learning A.I. models to predict how wildfires start and spread. Taylor Dinelli shared a video of her four-year- old daughter talking to an author who was sitting alone at a book signing event. The TikTok video got nearly 80 million views and author Jonathan Stanley`s book shot up Amazon`s bestseller list.

COY WIRE, CNN 10 ANCHOR: What`s up, sunshine? I`m Coy Wire. Welcome to CNN 10. I`m excited to be here kicking off another week of growth and opportunity with all of you.

Did you know that April 14th is Look Up at the Sky Day? So be sure to take a moment to slow down, take a deep breath or smell the flowers, cool the soup, calm all the noise, maybe do some cloud gazing and just be grateful for all those simple things in life we sometimes might take for granted.

For now, let`s get to your news. We start with an historic launch by the private spaceflight company Blue Origin, planning to launch the first all- female crew in over 60 years to the edge of space and back from its launch site in Texas. Among the six-person crew are notable names like journalist Gayle King, singer Katy Perry, and Lauren Sanchez, pilot, journalist and Vice Chair of the Bezos Earth Fund. She`s engaged to Amazon founder Jeff Bezos.

Joining them are film producer, Kerianne Flynn, former NASA rocket scientist, Aisha Bowe, and bioastronautics research scientist Amanda Nguyen. The suborbital space tourism mission will be fully autonomous with no pilots on board and it`ll last about 10 minutes.

The crew will travel just past the Karman line, a widely recognized demarcation of where space begins. It is at 100 kilometers or 62 miles above sea level. That`s where the crew will experience a few minutes of microgravity, not to mention tremendous views of Earth before returning home.

Our Isabel Rosales has more on this historic 31st flight of the New Shepard rocket.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Liftoff.

ISABEL ROSALES, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): For the first time in more than 60 years, an all-female crew is set to blast off into space.

Blue Origin`s star-studded NS31 mission is scheduled to launch from West Texas on April 14th on board the New Shepard vehicle. Among the six-person crew are singer, Katy Perry, journalist, Gayle King, and Lauren Sanchez, pilot and fiancee of Blue Origin founder, Jeff Bezos.

The crew is set to travel just past the Karman Line, the point widely recognized as where outer space begins, and will experience a few minutes of microgravity before descending back to Earth.

Crew member and former NASA rocket scientist, Aisha Bowe, spoke to CNN about her hope that this landmark voyage will inspire more women to shoot for the stars.

AISHA BOWE, FORMER NASA ROCKET SCIENTIST/BLUE ORIGIN CREW MEMBER: To see six women, who are all incredibly unique, who are very inspiring in their own right, come together and globally on a campaign.

I think what you`re going to see is not only more women, but more people know that they can too become one of us, and that they also can reach and work in these fields.

ROSALES: This will mark the first all-female space mission since Soviet Cosmonaut Valentina Tereshkova`s solo mission back in 1963.

But the historic mission has also faced criticism, including from actress, Olivia Munn. While co-hosting on NBC`s "Today" show with Jenna Bush Hager, Munn questioned the purpose of the mission and its cost.

OLIVIA MUNN, ACTRESS: What are they doing? Like, why? You know what I mean? Like, I`m just saying this. OK, I know this is probably not the cool thing to say, but like there are so many other things that are so important --

JENNA BUSH HAGER, HOST, "TODAY WITH JENNA AND FRIENDS": I know.

MUNN: -- in the world right now.

BUSH HAGER: I know, yes.

MUNN: Like, they aren`t asked. I mean, there`s one astronaut.

BUSH HAGER: One astronaut.

MUNN: But like, what are you guys going to do up in space? What are you doing up there?

ROSALES: One crew member, researcher and civil rights activist, Amanda Nguyen, will conduct experiments about women`s health during the 11-minute flight. Nguyen will make history becoming the first woman of Vietnamese or Southeast Asian descent in space.

Since their first successful crewed spaceflight in 2021, Blue Origin has had 10 crewed missions, bringing more than 50 people to the edge of space, including Star Trek actor, William Shatner, who was brought to tears by the experience.

WILLIAM SHATNER, ACTOR: I hope I never recover from this.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

WIRE: Pop quiz, hot shot. What famous mascot received so much fan mail that the post office assigned him his own zip code in 1964? Michelin Man, Smokey the Bear, Tony the Tiger, or Pillsbury Doughboy?

If you said Smokey Bear, smoking! In 1950, a bear cub rescued from a forest fire in New Mexico took over for Bambi as a symbol of forest fire prevention. And he can still send mail at Smokey Bear, Washington, D.C. 20252.

Smokey Bear has historically used his bear charm to inspire generations to help prevent fires, and now researchers are using artificial intelligence to help predict fires and stop them before they start. The European Center for Medium-Range Weather Forecasts is now using an AI-powered model to boost the accuracy of fire forecasts, incorporating data like fire patterns, potential fuel sources, and human activity into machine learning programs to improve on traditional weather models.

Our Derek Van Dam shows us how scientists hope this technology will save lives and homes from wildfires in the future.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

DEREK VAN DAM, CNN METEOROLOGIST (voice-over): Researchers in Europe are using the power of AI to predict where wildfires will break out before the first ember even ignites. Using machine learning, the European Center for Medium-Range Weather Forecasts has developed a new model that takes into account a variety of factors to determine areas at risk of wildfires.

JOE MCNORTON, ECMWF CLIMATE SCIENTIST: So historically for fire forecasting we use what`s called Fire Weather Index. And this is a simple physics space model where we use four weather variables, temperature, wind, precipitation, and humidity to forecast the chance that if a fire does occur how intense it will be.

So what we know from that is that it doesn`t account for a lot of things. It doesn`t account for fuel, it doesn`t account for ignition sources, and things like that. So what we try to do here is we try to incorporate more data into a machine learning framework.

DAM: For example, in the recent L.A. wildfires, unusual wet weather conditions leading up to the fires caused ample vegetation growth that was then made flammable by exceptionally dry weather in winter.

FRANCESCA DI GIOSEPPE, ECMWF PRINCIPAL SCIENTIST: So you see --

DAM: This new model would be able to take those factors into account and find the specific areas most at risk.

DI GIOSEPPE: This new method, the probability of fire, having the memory of the fuel abundance in their formulation allowed to really identify those regions that could be much more affected compared to simpler method they only consider weather. And this is why our prediction in this case was much more precise and pinpointed exact location when very close to Los Angeles where fire really occurred.

DAM: The danger wildfires pose is growing. Just last year wildfires forced the displacement of 800,000 people. The highest numbers since records began back in 2008. Researchers hope the model can be used by fire officials to identify areas at the most risk of fires and prevent them before they start, saving lives and homes in the process.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

WIRE: Today`s story getting a 10 out of 10, a mother-daughter duo going viral for one small act of kindness. They had an enormous impact. Taylor Dinelli and her four-year-old daughter were shopping at a Barnes & Noble. They saw a first-time author set up with his stack of books, hoping to sign some for people. Only problem was nobody came up to him. He was sitting there all alone. Like I always say, you are more powerful than you know. Take a look at how one powerful moment had an impact greater than they could have ever imagined.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Taylor Dinelli was shopping at a Barnes & Noble with her four-year-old daughter when they saw an author sitting alone at a book signing event.

TAYLOR DINELLI: We were there for probably half an hour and I didn`t really see anybody else going over to his table or anything like that. And I thought, yeah, that would be really nice. You know, I`m sure he would really appreciate if we went over and talked to him as well.

JONATHAN STANLEY, AUTHOR: This amazing four-year-old girl came marching up to me and she bravely said, I want to be an author when I grow up. And I just created my first book. And in that moment, it was such a special moment, she touched my heart.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Dinelli posted the encounter to TikTok, where it eventually got nearly 80 million views. Now Stanley`s book is listed as one of Amazon`s best sellers.

DINELLI: You know, I explained to her as much as you can explain to a four- year-old that we -- what we did really will change Mr. Stanley`s life and make his life a lot better. And her first, like without a second thought, she`s like, mommy, we can help everybody. Like we should keep helping people.

STANLEY: The video made an impact because she came into the moment with kindness and empathy. And it`s shown the world that kindness matters. It can change someone`s life. It changed mine.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

WIRE: Make someone smile today, y`all. You never know when, you never know how, but you may just be the spark of joy that someone needs today.

We are sending our shout out today to the Warriors at Tantasqua Regional Junior High School in Sturbridge, Massachusetts. Thank you for making us part of your day.

And thanks to all of you who`ve been commenting on our CNN 10 YouTube channel for your shout out requests. We are at 996,000 subscribers. So, so close to hitting a million. Thank you to all who have already joined the fam.

Rise up everyone and make it a great start to the week. I`m Coy Wire. We are CNN 10.

urn:contentItem:6F3K-M033-SCD0-20X4-00000-00Why Is Rocket Lab USA Stock Surging Today?2025-02-10T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:16:45ZLexisNexisUS NEWSWhy Is Rocket Lab USA Stock Surging Today?Shivani Kumaresan

Shares of aerospace manufacturer and launch service provider Rocket Lab USA, Inc. (NASDAQ:RKLB) are trading higher on Monday.

Over the weekend, the company successfully completed its 59th Electron mission. The mission saw the deployment of five satellites into Low Earth Orbit (LEO) for Kinéis, a French Internet-of-Things operator.

This launch is part of a five-mission contract between Rocket Lab and Kinéis, aimed at establishing the full Kinéis IoT constellation.

The "IOT 4 You and Me" mission launch occurred at 9:43 am NZDT (20:43 UTC) on February 9 from Rocket Lab's Launch Complex 1 in Mahia, New Zealand.

Also Read: Rivian Commercial Van Now Available For Fleets Nationwide In US

"That's four launches done and one still to go for Kinéis, then we'll have deployed their entire constellation in less than a year. It's not uncommon for constellation operators to wait longer than that for their first launch, let alone have a full constellation deployed and operating," said Rocket Lab founder and CEO Sir Peter Beck.

The date for the fifth and final launch scheduled to complete the deployment of the IoT constellation will be provided soon.

The five satellites were deployed into a 647 km low Earth orbit, joining the expanding Kinéis constellation, which will enable IoT devices to connect in remote regions across the globe.

This constellation will support essential functions such as forest fire detection, water management, infrastructure monitoring, and logistics tracking, ensuring connectivity in even the most remote areas of the planet.

Interest in companies like Rocket Lab has gained momentum after President Donald Trump's inaugural speech, where he promised to focus on space exploration and committed to sending astronauts to Mars.

According to Benzinga Pro, RKLB stock has gained over 530% in the past year.

Price Action: RKLB shares are trading higher by 8.41% at $29.71 at the last check Monday.

urn:contentItem:6FX1-9BN3-RW58-249Y-00000-00Volatus Aerospace Announces Broad National Expansion of Drone Operating Authorities Across Canada, Unlocking Scalable, High-Value Aerial Operations2025-05-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:16:45ZLexisNexisPRODUCT / SERVICES ANNOUNCEMENTVolatus Aerospace Announces Broad National Expansion of Drone Operating Authorities Across Canada, Unlocking Scalable, High-Value Aerial Operations

/ NOT FOR DISTRIBUTION TO UNITED STATES NEWSWIRE SERVICES OR FOR DISSEMINATION IN THE UNITED STATES /

TORONTO, May 27, 2025 (GLOBE NEWSWIRE) -- Volatus Aerospace Inc. (TSXV: FLT; OTCQX: TAKOF; Frankfurt: A2JEQU) (“Volatus”, or the “Company”), a leading provider of innovative aerial intelligence and logistics solutions, is proud to announce that Transport Canada has granted the Company additional nationwide Special Flight Operations Certificates (SFOC) that dramatically expand the scope and flexibility of Volatus’ commercial drone operations and allows for expanded use of the Company’s Operations Control Center (OCC) in Vaughan, ON.

Expanded Nationwide Drone Operating Authorities

Transport Canada has issued Volatus a newly amended SFOC unlocking a powerful suite of expanded drone operating privileges across Canada. These new authorities encompass operating procedure permissions that include:

Canada-Wide BVLOS Authorization for Drone Operations Day and NightTo conduct beyond visual line-of-sight (BVLOS) operations using small drones (250g to 25kg) across the country, both day and night in uncontrolled airspace, outside of aerodrome environments, expanding the previously announced authority for nation-wide BVLOS authority at night.

Proximity Flight Near InfrastructurePermission to operate an RPAS (Remotely Piloted Aircraft System) beyond visual line-of-sight without a pilot or visual observer maintaining visual contact within 100 feet vertically and 200 feet horizontally of structures such as buildings, towers, powerlines, and rail corridors, opening the door to close-proximity and long-range inspections, surveillance, and security patrols.

Access to Restricted and Controlled AirspaceApproval to operate within Class F restricted airspace and NOTAM-defined zones, enabling missions in complex or dynamically managed environments.

Operations in Northern Domestic AirspaceClearance for BVLOS drone flight operations at altitudes up to 400 feet AGL in Canada’s Northern Domestic Airspace, supporting high-latitude missions for environmental monitoring, infrastructure inspection, cargo delivery and Indigenous community services.

BVLOS Operations Without Visual ObserversSpecific authorization to operate RPAS beyond visual line-of-sight without the pilot or observer maintaining direct visual contact, leveraging Transport Canada-accepted detect-and-avoid technologies and operational protocols.

Support for Remote and Automated SystemsThis enables integration with automated and remote drone operations, including nested (drone-in-a-box) solutions through accepted SORA-based risk mitigation and oversight.

These regulatory advancements set the stage for scalable, automated, and commercially viable drone operations from coast to coast.

Why It Matters: Regulatory Momentum with Commercial Impact

Canada-Wide BVLOS, Day or Night – Using Transport Canada-accepted detect-and-avoid systems and safety protocols, Volatus is now authorized to fly drones across the country beyond visual line-of-sight, including at night. 

Heavy-Lift & High-Altitude Capability - The ability to fly certain drones over 25kg and above standard altitude ceilings unlocking extended operations in sectors such as cargo logistics, energy transmission line monitoring, search and rescue operations, and telecommunications tower inspections.

Wildfire Response & Restricted Airspace Access - Volatus can operate in wildfire restricted airspace during active wildfire events—supporting government and firefighting agencies with aerial intelligence, hotspot detection, and real-time situational awareness.

“With these approvals, Volatus can more significantly and on a wider basis, provide clients with nationwide BVLOS drone services at scale for clients in energy, telecom, transportation, agriculture, mining, and public safety,” said Rob Walker, Chief Commercial Officer for Volatus. “We can deploy heavier, longer-range drones capable of carrying larger payloads or extended sensors and we can commercialize our Operations Control Centre (OCC) offering a managed service for enterprise clients and partners—offering real-time drone oversight, mission management, and data collection including large scale deployment of drone-in-a-box solutions, nationwide with regulatory compliance.”

Building on a Growing Portfolio of Regulatory Approvals

These new authorizations build on the national nighttime BVLOS authority announced in March 2025, which permits drone operations beyond visual line-of-sight during legal night in uncontrolled airspace. In addition, Volatus holds a suite of existing and renewed Special Flight Operations Certificates (SFOCs) that collectively enable:

Fixed-Corridor BVLOS for Medical Drone Deliveries approving operations beyond visual line-of-sight flights between hospitals, enabling medical cargo deliveries over an urban-adjacent environment with regulatory oversight and OCC-managed safety protocols, with ground-based radar serving as the detect-and-avoid (DAA) mitigation.

High-payload operations with certain drones that exceed 25kg, supporting missions such as cargo transport, wildfire response, and infrastructure inspection.

Operations in restricted wildfire airspace for forest fire support missions, including BVLOS flights above 400 feet AGL under agreements with provincial fire authorities.

Altitude waivers for flights above standard ceiling limits in support of long-range and terrain-following missions.

Use of Foreign Operators and Pilots, recognition of foreign operator and pilot credentials allows Volatus to deploy its multinational pilot workforce seamlessly across operations. With certified pilots based in Canada, the United States, and the United Kingdom, this flexibility enables rapid mobilization, efficient cross-border coordination, and global service delivery under a unified operational framework.

Together, these approvals represent one of the most robust regulatory frameworks granted to any drone operator in Canada, positioning Volatus at the forefront of scalable, compliant, and high-impact drone services.

“These regulatory approvals don’t just reflect our technical readiness, they position us at the forefront of Canada’s evolving drone economy,” said Glen Lynch, CEO of Volatus. “With the ability to fly further, higher, heavier—at any time and in many location scenarios—we’re opening up a new scale of possibility for aerial intelligence and logistics.”

Positioned for Leadership

Volatus is among a select group of operators in Canada authorized to fly missions that meet Transport Canada’s highest accepted safety assurance level for complex drone operations – SAIL 4. “This means we’ve demonstrated that our technology, procedures, and risk mitigation strategies meet stringent safety standards required for higher-risk environments, including beyond visual line-of-sight flights in urban-adjacent areas. Operating at this level enables us to serve critical sectors, such as healthcare, infrastructure, and public safety—with safe, reliable, and compliant drone services at scale,” remarked Greg Colacitti, Chief Operating Officer for Volatus.

“These authorizations build upon one another to create an ecosystem where we can operate with flexibility, scale, and commercial viability,” Colacitti added. “They give us a distinct operational advantage and make us the partner of choice for organizations seeking scalable, safe, and high-performance drone operations in Canada and beyond.

About Volatus Aerospace:

Volatus Aerospace is a leader in innovative global aerial solutions for intelligence and cargo. With a strong foundation of over 100 years of combined institutional knowledge in aviation, Volatus provides comprehensive solutions using both piloted and remotely piloted aircraft systems (RPAS). We serve industries such as oil and gas, utilities, healthcare, and public safety. Our mission is to enhance operational efficiency, safety, and sustainability through cutting-edge, real-world solutions.

urn:contentItem:6G8M-NV13-RRYP-S1NM-00000-00Temperature mediated albedo decline portends acceleration of North American glacier mass loss2025-11-15T08:16:45Z2025-11-15T08:16:45ZLexisNexisTemperature mediated albedo decline portends acceleration of North American glacier mass loss

Supplementary informationThe online version contains supplementary material available at https://doi.org/10.1038/s43247-025-02503-x.Publisher’s note Springer Nature remains neutral with regard to jurisdictional claims in published maps and institutional affiliations.

Abstract

North American glaciers experienced accelerated mass loss over the last decade, yet the degree to which albedo decline drove this mass loss remains uncertain. We use daily summer glacier surface albedo averaged by decade (2000 − 2009 and 2010 − 2019) derived from Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer to investigate how snow and ice darkening influenced glacier mass loss for 25 of the largest and most heavily glaciated regions in North America. Here we show that glacier albedo respectively decreased by 0.019 ± 0.019 and 0.018 ± 0.009 in western North America and in the Canadian Arctic. This decrease in albedo coincides with increased geodetically derived glacier mass loss within these regions (R2 = 0.76, R2 = 0.63; p < 0.01). Modelled surface energy balance and melt rates, forced by European Centre for Medium-Range Weather Forecasts Reanalysis 5th Generation Land reanalysis and regional decadal averages of albedo, indicate that 31% of increased melt rate in Western North America and 41% of increased melt rate in the Canadian Arctic can be attributed to albedo decline. Projected increases in air temperature this century will further reduce glacier albedo, and the resulting positive feedback will further accelerate glacier mass loss.

Glacier albedo declined significantly over the past two decades, contributing to 31% and 41% of increased melt rates in Western North America and the Canadian Arctic respectively, according to a surface energy balance model forced by decadal reanalysis data and satellite albedo averages across 25 major glaciated regions.

IntroductionGlacier mass loss accelerated over the last 20 years1, 2–3 and excluding the Greenland and Antarctic Ice Sheets, mass loss from North America represents 49% of the global total1. Earth’s glaciers are projected with high confidence to lose 26–41% of their mass by the end of this century4. Sea level rise in the coming centuries is projected to exceed 2 m but with uncertain rates of change, which presents challenges in preparing for inundation and flooding5.

Accelerated mass loss of North American glaciers coincides with an increase in air temperature and dry conditions over the last decade1, but other factors such as how much solar radiation a glacier absorbs may also play an important role in explaining this acceleration. Absorbed solar radiation is controlled by surface albedo, which is the ratio of reflected to downwelling solar radiation ranging between zero and one. Temporal changes in albedo depend on many factors including temperature-mediated coarsening of snow grains6, the deposition of volcanic tephra and terrigenous dust7, industrial and forest-fire generated black carbon8, 9, 10–11 and algae growth12,13. The importance of albedo-driven changes in explaining observed accelerated mass loss remain uncertain.

Results

North American glacier albedo, air temperature and precipitation

We examine changes in glacier albedo for glaciated regions in both western North America and the Canadian Arctic (Fig. 1, Supplementary Table 1). Daily snow and ice albedo from Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS) Terra collection six for June-July-August (JJA) was subjected to quality control filtering and averaged using equal weighting for each 500 m grid cell inside glacier outlines in the Randolph Glacier Inventory 6.0 (RGI)14 zones one to four (“Methods”). These zones contain 15 distinct glacierized regions in western North America and 10 regions in Arctic Canada. The use of summer (JJA) values corresponds to maximum seasonal temperature and the main melt season for these ice masses and allows a standardised comparison of albedo across a large range of latitudes. Summer albedo declined between the two epochs (2010–19 versus 2000–09) for all glaciated regions except the northern portion of the US west Coast Cascades, where albedo increased by 0.015. The maximum albedo decrease was 0.055. Glacier retreat over the 20-year period can expose low-albedo ground or proglacial lakes, which would contaminate the signal of glacier albedo change, but we assessed this potential influence and conclude that this process has only minor influence on our results, i.e., our albedo change signal represents the supraglacial environment (Methods; Supplementary Figs. 1, 2). The effect of transient snow line rise is apparent at glacier median elevations (Supplementary Fig. 3) and represents a larger decline in albedo compared to the area above the median elevation, but not below. Aggregated albedo decreased by 0.019 ± 0.019 and 0.018 ± 0.009 in western North America and in the Canadian Arctic respectively.Fig. 1

The glaciated regions of western North America contained in the Randolph Glacier Inventory zones 1 to 4 were delineated into 25 regions.

Isolated small glaciers such as those in California, western Aleutian Islands, Vancouver Island, Labrador, and Melville Island have been omitted due to the spatial mismatch with the resolution of ERA5-Land. Albedo difference is the change between the 2010 and 2019 JJA average compared to 2000–2009. All regions show an albedo decline (yellow) except the United States Coast, which experienced an albedo increase of 0.015 (red). The size of the circle scales to the size of the albedo change. Details related to the specific regions and regional abbreviations can be found in Supplementary Table 1.

JJA average air temperatures in the ECMWF Reanalysis 5th Generation Land (ERA5–Land) climate reanalysis15 increased for all regions by as much as 1.1 °C (Supplementary Table 2). The average summer temperature increase for the 15 western glaciated areas is 0.58 °C ± 0.30 °C (one standard deviation) and the increase for the 10 Arctic areas is 0.47 °C ± 0.20 °C. There is a negative relation between JJA albedo and air temperature (p < 0.01, R2 = 0.69 during 2000–2009 and R2 = 0.70 for 2010 to 2019), and the cold Arctic temperatures correspond to higher average albedo (Fig. 2; Supplementary Tables 1, 2). Mean annual precipitation for the period 2010–2019 decreased within the middle latitudes of coastal western North America relative to the period 2000–2009 whereas high and low latitudes became wetter; this pattern was recognized in earlier studies1 and coincides with a shift in the average position of the mid-latitude jet16. Albedo increased in the U.S.Pacific Southwest (Oregon and Washington), coinciding with a 17% increase in precipitation. This regional increase in precipitation was the largest found in the study.Fig. 2

Paired change in air temperature and albedo for each glaciated area considered in this study.

a Open circles indicate the 2000–2009 averages and closed circles 2010–2019. Average summer albedo and air temperature display clustering related to latitude which corresponds to the RGI zone. Albedo correlates significantly (p«0.01) to air temperature for period 1 (R2 = 0.70) and period 2 (R2 = 0.69). An increase of one degree Celsius produces an approximate 0.04 decline in albedo. Red diamonds represent each glaciated region in the Arctic, while blue circles represent Western North America (b). The temporal change in albedo and air temperature do not display statistically significant correlations (b). Apart from the US coast, all regions show a decline in glacier albedo and increase in air temperature.

Albedo decline correlates to the increase in glacier mass loss

Total glacier mass loss strongly varies across regions of North America1. Most glaciers in the Canadian Arctic show a small increase of decadal mass loss (0.2 m we a−1) over the past decade, with the exception of Devon Island (southern RGI zone 3) and South Baffin (southern RGI zone 4) where the average mass loss decreased by 0.11 m we a−1. The Barnes ice cap, the remanent of the Laurentide Ice Cap, located in central Baffin Island, experienced high mass loss and attendant darkening with negligible changes in precipitation. Both western North America and Arctic Canada show similar rates of mass loss (−0.086 and −0.11 m we a−1 Δα−1) as a function of albedo decline (Fig. 3).Fig. 3

The relationship between geodetic mass balance difference and JJA average albedo difference between periods 2010–2019 and 2000–2009.

a The slopes of the relations between mass balance difference and albedo difference are similar for the two regions. The correlations are statistically significant for Arctic glacier regions (slope = 0.11 Δm we a−1/Δα, R2 = 0.63, p < 0.01) and for western North America glacier regions (slope = 0.086 Δm we a−1/Δα, R2 = 0.76, p < 0.01). There is essentially no correlations between average air temperature increase and geodetic mass balance decrease for the Arctic (R2 = 0.003, p > 0.05). Western North America shows a stronger correlation between air temperature change and albedo change(R2 = 0.34, p < 0.05), however this relationship to mass balance change is a weaker correlation than with albedo change (b) which is likely due to the near and below zero average melt season air temperature found in the Arctic. The grey shading indicates the 95% confidence interval of the trend lines.

Surface energy balance and melt modelling

To examine the role of albedo changes in contributing to the observed accelerated mass loss, we applied a surface energy and mass balance model for glaciers in western North America and Arctic Canada (“Methods”), driven by ERA5-Land climate forcing for the period 2000–2019. Surface energy balance and melt rates are calculated following the model of Ebrahimi and Marshall17, including a subsurface model of the coupled thermal and hydrological evolution in the upper 20 m of snow, firn, and ice18. The model includes parameterizations of meltwater percolation, refreezing, and the associated meltwater retention and latent heat release. The model uses standard formulations of glacier energy balance physics19,20.

The mass balance model is calibrated at Haig Glacier in the Canadian Rocky Mountains, where it can simulate annual mass balance and summer melt to within 10% of in situ observations21 when driven by local weather station data. There is greater uncertainty when forced with climate model output17 or applied to different glaciers, e.g., where surface albedo, roughness, debris cover, or katabatic wind regimes may differ. A surface energy balance melt model driven by ERA5 and ERA5-Land climate reanalyses can simulate melt rates within 10% of field observations in applications at four glaciers in western North America22. We are less confident in the uncalibrated application of the energy balance model to the considerably different environments across western and Arctic Canada, so use the model only in ‘perturbation’ experiments, where we examine the differential impact of different model forcings. Perturbation experiments reduce systematic biases in the simulations. For instance, if the model systematically overpredicts turbulent heat fluxes at a given site, it will do so in both a control experiment and with the perturbed forcing; this erroneous extra energy (melt) is removed when looking at the difference between the two simulations. We also specify the monthly albedo in summer months based on the MODIS data, controlling for one of the main uncertainties in the glacier energy balance modelling.

To isolate the effects of decadal meteorological vs. albedo changes on surface mass balance, we performed three experiments for each of the glacierized regions. A single central ERA5-Land grid cell for each of the 25 regions was used for modelling. We did not undertake distributed modelling of the glacier surface energy and mass balance over ensembles of glaciers, so no climate downscaling was necessary. Rather, our numerical experiments were ‘point’ studies of the sensitivity of glacier mass balance to albedo change across the 25 different climate regimes. The simulations used the observed (MODIS) monthly albedo values in each region, to constrain the simulations to the observed albedo conditions for each decade. The reference experiment thus prescribed monthly albedo values for two periods, 2000–2009 and 2010–2019. Surface energy and mass balance at each site were then modelled using the ERA5-Land hourly climatology with these fixed albedos. Perturbation experiments controlled for either albedo or the meteorological forcing, to isolate the effects of decadal-scale albedo vs. meteorological shifts on changes in mass balance. For the former, we held mean monthly albedo values from 2000–2009 constant through 2010–2019 for each site. In the second perturbation experiment, albedo was allowed to change while the meteorological forcing from 2000–2009 was repeated in the second decade. These numerical experiments allow us to attribute how much of the net mass balance reduction from 2010–2019 can be associated with albedo reductions vs. the direct meteorological forcing.

The average decadal summer temperature change (±1 standard deviation) across the 25 sites was ΔTJJA = 0.5 ± 0.3 °C in the ERA5-Land climatology. Regional temperature anomalies averaged 0.6 ± 0.3 °C for the western North American sites and 0.4 ± 0.3 °C in Arctic Canada. These values are close to those calculated from all ERA5-Land grid cells covering each region, as reported above. The numbers differ slightly because the energy balance model used a single representative ERA5-Land grid cell in each region. In the reference model that prescribes the observed albedo changes in each region with the full meteorological forcing, we simulate an average decadal mass balance change of Δbn = −0.20 ± 0.17 m w.e. a−1 across all sites. The modelled mass balance decrease in western North America was greater than in Arctic Canada, −0.26 ± 0.17 vs. −0.10 ± 0.12 m w.e. a−1 (Fig. 4a), although average decadal albedo changes were equivalent in western North America (−0.025) and the Canadian Arctic (−0.024).Fig. 4

Net mass balance sensitivity to decadal changes in atmospheric forcing and albedo for each of the glacier regions in this study.

Δbn is the difference in net mass balance from 2010 to 2019 relative to the period 2000–2009, and Δα is the corresponding decadal albedo change. a Mass balance change at all sites due to changes in both atmospheric forcing and albedo. b Mass balance change associated with just the albedo change, i.e., with no decadal climate forcing shift. The mass balance sensitivity to albedo change is estimated from the slope of the relations in (b), as per the regression lines: 0.036 ± 0.003 m w.e. Δα−1 in western North America (N = 15; R2 = 0.98) and 0.014 ± 0.017 m w.e. Δα−1 in Arctic Canada (N = 10; R2 = 0.32). Shaded regions in (b) indicate the 95% (2σ) confidence intervals. Relations with albedo are weaker in (a); the regression is significant in western North America (slope of 0.049 ± 0.034 m w.e. %−1; R2 = 0.42), but is not statistically significant in the Arctic.

The model experiments controlling for either albedo or the meteorological forcing yielded smaller changes in mass balance but some regional differences. Decadal mass balance anomalies due to atmospheric forcing in western and Arctic North America were Δbn = −0.18 ± 0.13 and −0.06 ± 0.11 m w.e. a−1, respectively. These values represent the mass balance change associated with the meteorological conditions, without any albedo feedback. From the other perturbation experiment, recycling the 2000–2009 atmospheric forcing for 2010–2019, we can quantify the additional mass loss associated with the albedo reductions (Fig. 4b), amounting to −0.08 ± 0.05 and −0.04 ± 0.07 m w.e. a−1 in the two regions. This is equivalent to 31% and 41% of the total decadal mass balance change in western and Arctic Canada, respectively. There is high variability in the mass balance signal across sites within each region.

There are strong linear relations between the decadal changes in albedo (Δα) and net mass balance (Δbn) in the two experiments, despite large differences in regional climatology for the 25 sites (Fig. 4). This can be defined as the mass balance sensitivity to changes in albedo, dbn /dα. Figure 4a includes both atmospheric forcing and albedo changes, while Fig. 4b plots the mass balance change associated with changes in albedo. The latter results indicate a mass balance sensitivity dbn /dα = 0.036 ± 0.003 m w.e. Δα−1 and 0.014 ± 0.017 m w.e. Δα−1 for western North America and Canadian Arctic glaciers, respectively, where the ± indicates the standard error in the slope. Both regressions are statistically significant at the p < 0.05 level. The regression results are relatively weak in the Canadian Arctic (R2 ~ 0.3), suggesting that the relation between net mass balance and albedo change may not be linear. It may also be a result of the relatively high inter-site variability and low sample size (N = 10). Furthermore, glaciers in western North America experienced greater sensible, latent, and net longwave heat fluxes in the 2010s (Fig. 5) that yielded significant difference in the net energy surplus: ΔQN = +10 W m−2 in western North America and ΔQN = +4 W m−2 in Arctic Canada, averaged over the summer months (JJA).Fig. 5

Discussion

We consider only surface mass balance processes in this study in terms of albedo dynamics and melt modelling: snow accumulation and melt at the glacier surface, which drives elevation changes (glacier thinning or thickening) that can be measured geodetically across large spatial scales1. Additional mass balance processes such as iceberg calving and marine melting can be important where glaciers are in contact with the ocean, and add to the glacier mass loss considered here. Frontal ablation in Alaska declined by 8%, increase by 3% in the Canadian Arctic North and did not change in the Canadian Arctic South between the 2010 and 2019 period compared to 2000 and 200923. Supplementary Fig. 4 shows the relationship between albedo difference and glacier mass balance difference for the regions containing marine terminating glaciers which originate in RGI 1, 3 and 4 between the 2010–2019 and 2000–2009 periods. Marine terminating glaciers show a larger increase in mass balance loss for the same amount of albedo change when compared to the ensemble of all glaciers by region, which is expected. However, the trend lines overlap in the 95% confidence interval indicating that the influence of iceberg calving in these regions is negligible compared to surface mass balance. There is also glacier mass loss associated with basal melting, but this is negligible for North American glaciers relative to surface melt rates.

Glacier mass loss associated with surface melting accelerated over the last 20 years1,3, linked to a rise in air temperature24. Energy available for glacier melt arises primarily from solar radiation and thermal energy, and albedo correlates strongly with mass balance of mid-latitude and Arctic glaciers25,26, where the majority of energy for melt is provided by solar radiation27,28. Absorbed solar energy, regulated by albedo, accounts for much of the spatial and temporal variability in melt rates across a glacier surface. Systematic albedo changes such as those documented here therefore contribute to important mass balance feedbacks and some of the observed acceleration of glacier melt.

Except for the northern United States coast, increases in precipitation do not coincide with an increase in summer albedo. Changes in precipitation (wetting or drying) present regional influence on mass balance, and are not as widespread as the observed increases in temperature. Increased mass loss concurs with dry conditions in middle latitudes in western North America1, but this pattern is not apparent elsewhere. Approximately half of the glacier regions in this study experienced an increase in precipitation. These increases did not increase albedo in most regions or reverse the trend in mass balance decline, likely because air temperature increase and the related albedo feedbacks are more influential than small precipitation increases.

Modelled surface mass losses (Fig. 4a) in western North America (−0.26 ± 0.17 m w.e. a−1) were about three times greater than in Arctic Canada (−0.10 ± 0.12 m w.e. a−1), reflecting differences in net energy (QN) available for melt between these regions. These rates are similar to observed decadal differences in geodetic mass losses1 in western North America (−0.30 m w.e. a−1) and Arctic Canada (−0.07 m w.e. a−1), but they are not directly comparable and they are not representing the same thing. The numerical experiments examine idealized changes in surface mass balance for each region using a single grid point, while the geodetic mass change estimates of Huggonet et al.1 are distributed values covering the entire ensemble of glaciers in each region. These also include effects such as calving that are not represented in our surface mass balance model.

Our model experiments were designed to estimate the portion of the decadal mass balance loss that could be attributed to albedo change vs. atmospheric forcing (Table 1), as represented in the ERA5-Land meteorological reconstructions for each region. Overall, 69% of the glacier mass balance perturbation in western North America in the 2010s can be attributed to the meteorological forcing and 31% is directly associated with the albedo change. In Arctic Canada, 59% of the additional mass loss in the 2010s is attributed to climate forcing and 41% is associated with declines in albedo. The albedo change represents a net shortwave radiation forcing of about +3 W m−2 in each region. Any albedo decline at the MODIS grid cell level that is not associated with snow or ice (such as sub grid area decline at a glacier edge) would lead to arbitrary albedo decline and cause the model to over estimate melt. Although we cannot discount this reduction entirely, we have shown that this effect is negligible in comparison to albedo decline caused by temperature mediated snow, firn and ice albedo decline. Past work shows that the change in seasonal snow cover, which describes a rising transient snow line, is a small portion of the albedo change, when integrated over the whole of a glacier11. An increase in transient Arctic glacier snow line by approximately 150 m over the course of 1984 to 2022 has been reported29. The albedo changes within 100 metres of a glacier median elevation (Supplementary Fig. 3) does not consistently show a larger albedo decline compared to the lowest portion of glaciers. The albedo declines on glaciers above 100 m of median elevation are consistently smaller than below. This is especially true for the highest mountain regions in the Yukon and Alaska where no declines are visible, which corroborates earlier albedo trend analysis for the Saint Elias Range30. It appears albedo decline caused by rising snow line is occurring but is not the exclusive factor controlling regional albedo change.Table 1

Despite comparable levels of warming, incoming shortwave radiation, and albedo change across western and Arctic North America, the glaciers of western North America displayed a much greater mass balance response to the decadal shifts in climate forcing and albedo. Our sensitivity experiments allowed an examination of the surface energy balance processes that contribute to this differing response. The muted response in the Arctic is largely due to the colder snow and firn conditions. Mean annual temperature for the ERA5-Land grid cells representing the Arctic sites is −16 °C, compared with −2.5 °C for the western North American sites. A colder surface partitions more energy to warming, which leaves less available for driving melt. Colder surface conditions in the Arctic also allow for greater internal refreezing and meltwater retention, supported by the thick firn zones that are typical at the median elevation of Canada’s high Arctic ice caps. Meltwater refreezing reduces the net loss of mass from the glacier system. There are also subtle but systematic negative energy balance feedbacks associated with colder air and snow temperatures in the Arctic.

Our results emphasize the importance of albedo variations and feedbacks in governing glacier mass balance and its response to changes in climate forcing. Such feedbacks are generally absent within global-scale models of glacier mass balance, which tend to use temperature-index (e.g., degree-day) melt models rather than a physically-based surface energy balance. This is a reasonable pragmatic consideration, as the meteorological forcing fields that are needed for energy balance modelling are not available at the resolution that is required for distributed modelling of mountain glaciers31. The lack of including these effects, however, implies that simulations of large ensembles of mountain glaciers and their response to changes in climate forcing are missing important physical processes and feedbacks, particularly with respect to systematic changes in albedo.

Temperature-index melt models typically apply a constant melt factor that is differentiated for snow and ice32. The melt factor for ice is larger than for snow, implicitly accounting for the differences in ice and snow albedo. The assignment of the ice or snow melt factor can use albedo as a tuning parameter in large scale modelling33,34, but most of these models neglect spatial and temporal variations in albedo. Similarly, temperature-index models that include potential direct solar radiation have a radiation melt factor that can be tuned, but this modulates potential direct vs. actual incoming solar radiation, so is a proxy for atmospheric (e.g., cloud) conditions as well as surface albedo. Physically-based albedo models that directly address albedo evolution and its influence on melt energy are not yet included in large-scale models of glacier mass balance.

We show that a 0.5 °C summer temperature increases correlate to an approximate 0.02 albedo reduction for North American glaciated regions (Fig. 2). Extrapolating from this, the projected warming by mid century by 1–2 °C under the RCP 4.5 and RCP 8.5 scenarios35 would lead to an additional albedo decline of 0.04 to 0.08. The relationship between mass loss and albedo decline is approximately −0.1 m w.e.a.−1 Δα−1, which can be corrected for the regional influence of albedo decline from the surface energy balance and melt model. The amount of additional melt directly related to projected albedo decline is 0.12–0.25 m w.e.a.−1 in western North America and 0.17–0.34 m w.e.a.−1 in the Canadian Arctic, providing the rate of additional mass loss to albedo decline remains unchanged over the next several decades. Recent findings show that CMIP temperature projections for the Arctic are extremely conservative36 which indicates glacier albedo decline and melt rates under current RCP pathways are low estimates.

Precipitation increases might countervail albedo and mass balance declines, but for this to occur any precipitation increases will have to be on the order of those observed in the coastal region of the United States. The US coast saw an average increase in precipitation of ~250 mm per year, which was more than twice the next biggest increase and 10 times larger than the average precipitation change for all of the regions considered here. Projections show global average precipitation will increase35. Under RCP 8.5, which features the largest precipitation increase of all pathways, the precipitation increase by mid-century is approximately 3.5%. Although regional differences will modify this global average, it is unlikely that widespread precipitation increases under RCP 8.5 will be equivalent to the 17% found on the US Coast through the 2010s. Based on these numbers and empirical evidence from the past decade, expected gains in precipitation are unlikely to compensate for the additional melt associated with temperature increase and will not be large enough to offset albedo declines. Coincident with warming and increasing precipitation is a rising snow-line and an increased fraction of liquid precipitation, both of which will further lower glacier albedo.

Albedo declines related to wildfires generated aerosol deposition might further increase glacier melt rates. The size and frequency of North American wildfires are projected to increase as a response to warming37,38. Currently, the deposition of forest fire aerosols appears to reduce glacier albedo in the southern interior portions of western North America11 and Arctic glaciers will likely not be affected over the next several decades. Wildfire generated soot can persist on glaciers and cause a lagged albedo decline that can increase glacier melt by up to 10% several years after deposition39. Any mechanism that reduces albedo beyond what temperature projections predict, such as forest fires aerosol deposition, will provide an additional amount of melt which is currently unaccounted for.

Methods

Snow and ice albedo

The albedo data used in our study originates from the MODIS sensor on the Terra satellite. Terra is in a near-polar sun synchronous descending orbit and acquires data with the MODIS sensor over a spectral range of 0.459–14.385 µm in 36 spectral bands. Equatorial overpass times for Terra is approximately 10:30 AM local time. MODIS Snow albedo (MOD10A1, collection 6) is produced following the algorithm described in Klein and Stroeve40. An anisotropic function corrects for scattering effects from snow in non-forested regions. Slope and aspect for the correction is derived from the Global 30 Arcsecond (GTOPO30) digital elevation model (DEM). Daily snow albedo is produced in 500 m grid cells for cloud-free conditions from the best single daily observation, which is determined by an algorithm that ingests illumination and satellite view angles, in addition to cloud mask and fractional snow cover41. Normalised Difference Snow Index (NDSI) is used to identify the presence of snow within a MODIS grid cell. The absence of snow removes the grid cell from the processing train. MODIS Terra daily snow albedo is stored as unsigned 8-bit. Albedo is recorded in a range of 0–100. Cloud cover and other ancillary data are assigned unique values between 101 and 254 by group. The MODIS basic Quality Assessment (QA) for each albedo grid cell was analysed and high quality and good quality data were retained for analysis. Most data that were removed originated on a particular day versus being spread throughout the time series of daily images. The daily images with a high proportion of Quality Flags issued were removed from the generation of monthly averages. Terra data from 2000 to 2019 was available except for days of year (doy) 219–230 in 2000 (middle of August).

The accuracy of Collection five MOD10A1 albedo is assessed by comparison to field measurements. Stroeve et al.42 found the comparison to be ±0.07, on Greenland Ice Sheet. In the St. Elias Mountains, the comparison was found to be within ±0.06 for a variety of glaciated terrain43. Ryan et al.44 observed that surface-based albedo measurements overestimate MOD10A1 (Collection six) albedo by up to 0.10 for bare ice surfaces during the summer melt season on the Greenland Ice Sheet. This overestimation is because meteorological station footprints poorly estimate inter grid cell albedo variability, due to under-sampling of surficial meltwater. Sensor degradation is a likely source of MODIS Terra albedo values being too low45,46 and the resulting albedo trends obtained for the Greenland Ice Sheet of 0.01 decade−1 are close to the sensor calibration limit. Sensor degradation issues found in the collection five albedo data have been corrected in collection six46. Snow albedo from Terra and Aqua MODIS sensors is strongly correlated with a root mean squared error (RMSE) of 0.97% for five glaciated regions in south western North America11. When regressed against year, the difference (Terra minus Aqua) by region span −0.0012 to −0.046 α% a−1 with a mean difference of −0.018 α% a−1, indicating that Terra albedo is declining slower than Aqua. Furthermore, the regressions were not statistically significant indicating that MOD10A1 is not skewed by sensor calibration drift. The comparison of albedo data collected by MODIS Aqua and Terra is difficult because of variations in view angles, solar zenith angles and diurnal changes in albedo that can be asymmetrical around solar noon47. Moreover, there are relative calibration differences between MODIS sensors. These difficulties also present challenges to trend detection.

This study used 15 distinct regions in western North America outlined by Randolph Glacier Inventory 6.0 polygons (Fig. 1, Table 1) approximating regional boundaries described in previous studies48,49 and 10 regions in the Canadian Arctic. We averaged MODIS Terra MOD10A1 daily snow albedo using equal weighting by the calendar month for June, July and August for each 500 m grid cell inside of RGI glacier polygons. The average albedo excluded cloud cover and daily values that were flagged as poor quality. To reduce bias due to misclassified clouds and snow, we compared the MODIS daily albedo product against the typical ranges for glacier snow and ice albedo50. Albedo values > 0.99 for snow or glacier ice and were excluded and albedo values < 0.05 were considered shadow influenced and were excluded. Albedo values lower than pure ice but larger than 0.05 were considered valid, as they could represent melt ponds, or ice overlain by debris, dust or other contaminants. Albedo was aggregated by an equal weighted average of all valid grid cell values within each glacier polygon outline before it was again aggregated by equal weighted average for each of the twenty five regions.

We investigated how edge effects influence albedo. This analysis dictated that regional averages were calculated directly without averaging by RGI polygon. Each MODIS grid cell was assigned a value of 1–9 to represent the number of proximate grid cells from August average albedo. A value of one indicates no surrounding MODIS grid cells; a value of nine indicates a snow or ice grid cell that is surrounded (four edges and four vertices) by eight snow and ice grid cells. Regionally, large differences exist in the proportion of grid cell proximity to other grid cells (Supplementary Fig. 1). For example, Barnes Ice Cap contains approximately 90% of grid cells that only share edges with other ice grids, 9 classified grid cells, which is what is expected for an ice cap. There is no correlation between average grid cell proximity and albedo change regionally (Supplementary Fig. 2). Regions with larger glaciated area show higher average proximity values. Furthermore, there are no statistically significant trends when removing the US Coast, which displays an increase in albedo. The two regions which appear to show a decrease in albedo in relation to having low proximity values (the Northern Interior and Northern Rockies) are smallest and fourth smallest glaciated regions in the study area. These regions have little influence on North American glacier mass loss.

Glacier median elevation for each glacier polygon in RGI 1–4 was obtained from the RGI glacier polygon files. Every MODIS albedo 500 m grid cell which intersected a glacier polygon had its elevation extracted from the USGS bare earth digital elevation resampled to the MODIS grid cell spacing from the native 90 m (3 arcseconds) resolution. Each glacier’s snow and ice albedo values were separated into three elevation groups and then aggregated by direct mean to produce zone averages. The groups were less than 100 metres below a glacier’s median elevation, within 100 metres of median elevation and greater than 100 metres of median elevation (Supplementary Fig. 3).

ERA 5—land reanalysis data

Monthly ERA5-Land re-analysis15 of 2 m air temperature and total precipitation at 9 km grid cells that intersected with glacier polygons in RGI 1 to 4 were retained for analysis. ERA 5—Land air temperature correlates well with in situ measurements on glaciers51. JJA air temperature is strongly dependent on the region where a range of 3 °C to 10 °C is found on the west coast and the Canadian Arctic displays a range between −4 °C and 2 °C. ERA 5—Land monthly precipitation covered the entire year, whereas temperature values from June, July and August were analysed. The ERA data was further filtered by excluding 9 km grid cells that contained less than 33% coverage by 500 m MODIS albedo grid cells. The annual data were averaged (Temperature) or summed (Total Precipitation). These annual data were then averaged into decadal averages for 2000–2009 and 2010–2019.

We excluded Aleutian Island glaciers west of Fox Islands (53.14 N; −168.62) and California glaciers. The large spatial mismatch between MODIS and ERA 5—Land grids dictated that only ERA 5—Land grids that covered 1/3 or greater MODIS albedo grids were retained for analysis. This filtering step excluded four regions from the 29 total regions because of their small size, isolation and lack of contiguous ice area. These locations include the glaciated regions in Wyoming (continental USA), the Torngats (Labrador, Canada), Melville Island (Arctic Canada) and Vancouver Island (Canadian west coast).

Geodetic mass balance

Area normalised mass balance for the periods 2000–2009 and 2010–2019 was obtained from Hugonnet et al.1. Mass change data representing each glacier polygon within RGI zones one to four were averaged into the corresponding region identified for albedo trend detection.

Surface energy balance and melt modelling

Net energy at the surface, QN, is calculated from the sum of the energy fluxes towards the surface layer,1where QS↓ and QS↑ = αQS↓ denote the incoming and outgoing shortwave radiation, for surface albedo α, QL↓ and QL↑ are the incoming and outgoing longwave radiation, and QH, QE, and QC represent the sensible, latent, and conductive heat fluxes. All fluxes have units W m−2 and are defined as positive when they are sources of energy to the surface.

The required meteorological forcing for the model includes incoming shortwave and longwave radiation, wind speed, air temperature, humidity, and air pressure. Sensible and latent heat flux are calculated from these meteorological fields and conductive heat fluxes are calculated within the subsurface model. Outgoing longwave radiation, QL↑, follows Stefan-Boltzmann’s equation, QL↑ = σ εsTs4, for surface emissivity εs = 0.98, Stefan-Boltzmann’s constant σ, and absolute temperature of the surface layer, Ts, which is calculated from the subsurface model. When the surface layer is below 0 °C, any surplus or deficit of energy drives warming or cooling the snow, firn, or ice. When at the melting point, 0 °C, surplus net energy (i.e., QN > 0) is directed to melting, following2where is the melt rate (m s−1), is the density of water, and Lf is the latent heat of fusion. Integrated over the summer melt season, Eq. (2) provides an estimate of the total snow and ice melt, m. Some amount of this melt may refreeze in the snow and firn, denoted ϕ. Where this is retained through the summer, the meltwater runoff from a site is m − ϕ. The summer mass balance is then equal to bs = − (m − ϕ).

The energy balance model is forced by hourly meteorological fields from the ERA5-Land climate reanalysis for the 20-year period 2000–201915. These fields are extracted from the 0.1° ERA5-Land grid cells corresponding to one centroid location for each of the 25 glacier regions reported in Supplementary Table 1. The model is run year-round to capture the subsurface temperature evolution, heat flux, and meltwater retention to 20-m depth, but results reported here are restricted to the summer months, June through August. Surface albedo is prescribed from the observed MODIS June, July, and August values for the median glacier elevation in each glacier region. September through May albedo values in the simulations are assigned a fresh-snow value of 0.86. Annual snow accumulation (winter mass balance, bw), is estimated from the ERA5-Land September through May total precipitation. Net annual mass balance, bn, is calculated from the sum of the ERA5-Land derived winter mass balance and the modelled summer mass balance: .

The model needs to be initialized for the firn temperature and water/ice content. This is done through a 20-year “spin-up” simulation with the model forced by cycling 2000–2009 meteorological conditions. This is sufficient to develop initial conditions for the 20-m firn layer at each site, but it is more complicated where modelled annual ablation exceeds the accumulation, i.e., where the climatology is consistent with the ablation zone. In this case the 20-m firn layer is allowed to thin and may reach 0 thickness (i.e., a bare-ice surface). Such cases mimic nature (i.e. the current loss of firn zones on glaciers), but are not constrained by observations in our case. The effect on the modelled differential mass balance is believed to be small, as QC is a small term in the heat budget, meltwater refreezing is modest at sites where this could be an issue (i.e., in western Canada), and the differential results will minimize systematic biases such as neglect of meltwater refreezing.
